content: This usually happens due to folder re-sync issues, server-side changes, account reconfiguration, or profile inconsistencies in Thunderbird. In many cases, emails are not permanently deleted, but the folder is no longer visible or mapped correctly. When system folders like Deleted / Trash disappear, Thunderbird may stop syncing those emails correctly. If the issue isnâ€™t addressed early, users can lose access to emails that still exist in backups or archives. If the Deleted folder has vanished and emails are no longer accessible through Thunderbird, BitRecover Thunderbird Converter provides a safe alternative to bring back previously stored or archived mailbox data directly into Thunderbird, without relying on server synchronization.
creator: khushiratra.pcvita

content:
You're speaking to other users here. I did no such thing to you. This is not a general Firefox or Thunderbird problem, but a system defaults issue.

It would be helpful if you told us what version of Thunderbird you are using and what your computer operating system is. I'll assume it's the latest Windows 11. Try this solution. Substitute your browser of choice for Chrome. You might have to change the default a couple of times for it to stick.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1525950

This worked for me. I changed from Firefox to Edge and back and it worked as expected.
creator: rednoise

content: This is almost certainly a server problem that you can't resolve on your own. It usually means the sending (SMTP) server has gone off-line. However, in one recent case, it turns out the the error message was misleading, and that the email provider had changed their server address but neglected to tell their users. Can you contact your mail host support (on-line or by phone) and confirm the email settings and inquire if they are having system problems?
creator: rednoise

content:
Can you be more specific about "will not read it" means? Any error messages? I'm not aware of an incompatibility between Ver. 146 and 147, but I could have missed it. In general, I have not had any major issues transferring profiles from near versions between Windows and Linux (Mint and Ubuntu.)

There is a possible issue in both Windows and Linux about exporting profiles larger than 2 GB. Could that be the case here? If so, the profile can be copied and imported manually. Please ask if you'd like instructions.
creator: rednoise

content: It only affects some emails, mostly from institutions but also from a couple of individuals. Most personal emails come thru fine. Attached screen shots of filter (I believe this is a Thunderbird "stock" filter?) and two sample log entries.

content: My suggestion is to change the filter so that you know exactly what is being checked. The fact that mail is getting through indicates that the actual filtering is now what you understand. I suggest something such as 'from' 'does not contain' @ Might that work? All email addresses have a @ sign. That may not be perfect, but it may be a start.
creator: davidsk

content: There is no known limit of the number of accounts you can have. If you run into one, it probably would be either a bug in how many accounts the folder pane can display or due to "Use Global Inbox" being checked for that account. 1000 accounts sounds ambitious though.
